questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of well-controlled hypertension reports for evaluation of multiple concerns. He reports that he developed an upper respiratory tract infection 10 days ago, followed by a blocked-up feeling with reduced hearing in his right ear that did not respond to decongestants. Two days ago, he had nausea with vomiting, which is slowly resolving. Since then, he has had persistent vertigo. He notes new onset of a high-pitched noise in his right ear.
He has no history of head or neck trauma and reports no prior history of hearing loss or tinnitus. He has not traveled in 2 months. He is presently taking lisinopril and chondroitin sulfate.
His vital signs are normal, and he is not orthostatic. He appears well. His cardiovascular and neurologic examinations, including cranial nerves II-VII and IX-XII, are normal. His pharynx is mildly erythematous, with no tonsillitis. There is no lymphadenopathy. His ear canals are clear of cerumen. His Rinne test is positive bilaterally, and his Weber test lateralizes to the left. He has left-beating horizontal nystagmus that is worse on right lateral gaze.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ménière disease is characterized by fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, aural fullness, and recurrent severe vertigo with nausea and vomiting that lasts 30 minutes to many hours. Between episodes, the patient’s balance is normal. Typically, patients are older than age 50 with slowly progressing tinnitus and deafness in one ear (or, rarely, both) who suddenly develop severe vertigo that worsens over several minutes.

B) CORRECT:

The symptom of vertigo is defined as an illusion of movement of self or surroundings. The absence of any noted weakness, impaired speech, or diplopia in this patient makes a peripheral cause of vertigo — such as benign positional vertigo, labyrinthitis, vestibular neuritis, recurrent vestibulopathy, or drug effects — most likely.

The Rinne test is performed by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid process until sound is no longer heard; the fork is then immediately placed just outside the ear. In a normal ear, air conduction is better than bone conduction, and the patient can therefore hear the sound again when the tuning fork is moved from the mastoid process (bone) to outside the ear (air); this is known as a positive Rinne test.

In the Weber test, the tuning fork is placed in the middle of the skull, and the patient determines on which side the sounds can be heard most clearly. In this patient, the Weber test lateralizes to the left ear, which is consistent with sensorineural hearing loss on the right, a feature of labyrinthitis.

Labyrinthitis, the most likely diagnosis for this patient, is a peripheral vertigo associated with hearing loss that typically develops after a systemic viral illness. Nausea and vomiting are present when the labyrinthitis is severe. Tinnitus can also be seen. On examination, the patient will have a positive Rinne test bilaterally with better air conduction than bone conduction. The Weber test will lateralize to the ear with normal hearing, consistent with sensorineural hearing loss of the ear affected by the labyrinthitis. Patients may have a positive head-thrust test and nystagmus that does not change direction and is directed toward the uninvolved ear.

Key learning point: Labyrinthitis can be distinguished from vestibular neuritis by examining the patient’s hearing. Auditory function is preserved in patients with vestibular neuritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Many drugs may affect the inner ear. Most affect both vestibular and cochlear mechanisms, but the degree varies. Aspirin, for example, primarily affects cochlear function; high doses produce bilateral tinnitus and hearing loss without much vertigo. Common toxins include aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, cytotoxic agents, anticonvulsants, and alcohol. This patient’s medications — lisinopril and chondroitin — are not associated with vertigo.

D) INCORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis (vestibular neuronitis) is peripheral vertigo without hearing loss; it is secondary to inflammation of the eighth cranial nerve's vestibular segment. The patient has sudden onset of severe, constant vertigo that is exacerbated by head movement and that resolves over days to weeks. The patient may complain of fullness in the ear or tinnitus. The patient may have had an upper respiratory infection in the preceding 2 to 3 weeks. The symptoms may last days.

E) INCORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is the most common cause of vertigo. In contrast to viral labyrinthitis, BPPV tends to be acute in onset, without hearing loss, and is associated with episodic vertigo that is triggered by head turning. The dizziness typically lasts less than a minute and can be accompanied by nausea.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of acute-onset, room-spinning vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and gait unsteadiness. Her symptoms do not improve in any position or worsen with certain movements. She has had an upper respiratory infection for the past 5 days but is otherwise healthy. She denies sensitivity to light or sound.
On tuning-fork examination, the patient's Weber test is midline, and the Rinne test is positive (i.e., air conduction is better than bone conduction) bilaterally. The results of otoscopic examination are normal. Hearing is intact to whisper bilaterally. She has mild rhinorrhea.
Cranial-nerve function is normal except for fast-beating nystagmus to the left that diminishes when the patient focuses on the clinician’s finger. Romberg testing reveals swaying to the right, and the patient is able to walk carefully. Rapid movement of her head to the right while focusing on the clinician’s nose reveals a quick corrective saccade to regain focus. To the left, she is able to remain focused on the clinician’s nose despite a rapid head thrust.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), the vertigo is triggered by particular head movements and lasts seconds to minutes, with nystagmus to the involved side. When the patient does not move, the symptoms fully resolve. The nystagmus elicited by the Dix-Hallpike maneuver in a patient with BPPV is often a mixed torsional and vertical nystagmus.

B) INCORRECT:

Meniere disease involves recurring vertigo, hearing loss, aural fullness, and tinnitus. It is difficult to diagnose on the basis of an isolated episode, but this patient does not exhibit the tinnitus and change in hearing that are usually associated with Meniere disease. Furthermore, the severe vertigo usually lasts only 30 minutes to 3 or 4 hours.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral meningitis can occur after an upper respiratory tract infection, but typically it is associated with headache, stiff neck, and signs of central involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Vertebrobasilar ischemia and other central causes of vertigo are associated with a negative head-thrust test, direction-changing nystagmus that does not fatigue, severe postural instability, and frequently other neurologic findings.

E) CORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis, a syndrome caused by inflammation of the vestibular nerve, is often preceded by an upper respiratory infection. Symptoms include acute prolonged vertigo (lasting days), spontaneous nystagmus, postural imbalance, and nausea without accompanying cochlear or neurologic symptoms. Peripheral lesions result in unidirectional, fatigable nystagmus with horizontal and often torsional components, a positive head-thrust test, and mild-to-moderate postural instability. Central lesions would cause nystagmus of any trajectory, including purely vertical nystagmus and nystagmus that does not diminish with visual fixation. Central lesions are associated with severe postural instability and often have additional neurologic findings, such as cranial nerve abnormalities, limb dysmetria, and dysphagia.

Key learning point: The combination of acute prolonged vertigo, spontaneous nystagmus, postural imbalance, and nausea without accompanying cochlear or neurologic symptoms is suggestive of vestibular neuritis.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 64 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I feel very dizzy.”
History of Present Illness:


2-day history of persistent dizziness that has been getting worse
severe nausea with 7 episodes of vomiting since yesterday
has difficulty walking in a straight line
history of upper respiratory tract infection 8 days ago

no history of recent travel or head trauma

Past Medical History:


3-year history of diabetes mellitus

5-year history of hypercholesterolemia

5-year history of hypertension

7-year history of sinus node dysfunction with symptomatic bradycardia treated with permanent pacemaker implantation

Medications: 

metformin
atorvastatin
lisinopril

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

father: deceased at age 56 years from myocardial infarction
mother: alive with no chronic conditions

Psychosocial History:

drinks 5 beers and several shots of vodka daily
does not smoke cigarettes

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.7°C(98.0°F)
87/min
17/min
140/90 mm Hg
97% on RA
155 cm(5 ft 1 in)
61 kg(135 lb)
26 kg/m2




Appearance: alert; visibly uncomfortable
HEENT: PERRLA; spontaneous horizontal nystagmus in the right eye with the fast phase beating toward the left; nystagmus disappears when the patient looks to the right; no vertical misalignment on the alternate cover test; impaired vestibuloocular reflex in the right eye; external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane are intact bilaterally; Rinne test positive bilaterally; Weber test lateralized to the left

Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: nondistended; nontender to palpation
Neurologic: fully oriented; normal muscle tone; no tremors; sensation to light touch and temperature intact; muscle strength 5/5 throughout; mild gait ataxia



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Labyrinthitis, a subtype of vestibular neuritis, is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and AVS from a peripheral cause. This condition is caused by inflammation of the membranous labyrinth that is usually idiopathic, autoimmune, or caused by a viral (e.g., following an upper respiratory infection) or bacterial infection (e.g., as a complication of otitis media). Labyrinthitis causes decreased vestibular activity and typically manifests with nystagmus toward the healthy ear. Diagnosis is clinical and does not routinely require neuroimaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Bradyarrhythmia or tachyarrhythmia resulting from pacemaker failure can lead to dizziness as a result of presyncope. However, this patient has a normal heart rate with a regular rhythm. Moreover, presyncope usually lasts seconds to minutes and is not associated with nystagmus, nausea, or vomiting. This patient's presentation is consistent with dizziness due to vertigo.

C) INCORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a peripheral cause of vertigo. However, episodes of BPPV are typically sudden, brief (< 1 minute), and triggered by certain head movements. Moreover, hearing loss is not expected in BPPV.

D) INCORRECT:

An ischemic stroke affecting the posterior circulation can cause vertigo. However, an ischemic stroke causes central vertigo, which manifests with a normal head impulse test, central-type nystagmus (e.g., direction-changing, vertical, or torsional nystagmus), or skew deviation on the HINTS examination. This patient has a peripheral cause for vertigo.

E) INCORRECT:

Wernicke encephalopathy can occur in patients with a history of heavy alcohol use and manifests with ataxia and features of oculomotor dysfunction such as horizontal nystagmus. However, this condition typically causes gaze-evoked nystagmus in both eyes, unlike the spontaneous unilateral nystagmus in this patient. Moreover, hearing loss is not expected in Wernicke encephalopathy, and the patient does not present with other clinical features of this condition such as disorientation, impaired vigilance, and cognitive deficits.
questions.hint: The presence of gait instability, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting indicate that vertigo due to acute vestibular syndrome (AVS) is the most likely cause of this patient's acute-onset dizziness. The presence of all of the following on HINTS examination strongly suggests peripheral vertigo: spontaneous unidirectional horizontal nystagmus, absent skew deviation, and abnormal head impulse test (i.e., impaired vestibuloocular reflex).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of acute, room-spinning vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and gait unsteadiness. Her symptoms do not improve in any position or worsen with certain movements. She has had an upper respiratory infection for the past 5 days. On physical examination, there is fast-beating nystagmus to the left that diminishes when the patient focuses on the examiner's finger. Romberg testing reveals swaying to the right. Rapid movement of her head to the right while focusing on the examiner's nose reveals a quick corrective saccade to regain focus. To the left, she is able to remain focused on the examiner's nose despite a rapid head thrust. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A) INCORRECT:

It is difficult to diagnose on the basis of an isolated episode, but this patient does not exhibit the tinnitus and change in hearing that are usually associated with Meniere disease. Furthermore, the severe vertigo usually lasts only 30 minutes to 3 or 4 hours.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral meningitis can occur after an upper respiratory tract infection, but typically it is associated with headache, stiff neck, and signs of central involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Vertebrobasilar ischemia and other central causes of vertigo are associated with a negative head-thrust test, direction-changing nystagmus that does not fatigue, severe postural instability, and frequently other neurologic findings.

E) CORRECT:

Central lesions are associated with severe postural instability and often have additional neurologic findings, such as cranial nerve abnormalities, limb dysmetria, and dysphagia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic because of dizziness. Ten days ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection, after which he developed a feeling of fullness and decreased hearing in his right ear that did not improve with decongestants. Two days ago, he developed nausea and vomiting, followed by persistent vertigo. He also reports a new high-pitched noise in his right ear. He has hypertension managed with lisinopril. On examination, Rinne test is positive bilaterally, and Weber test lateralizes to the left. He has left-beating horizontal nystagmus that is worse on right lateral gaze. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The dizziness typically lasts less than a minute and can be accompanied by nausea.

Vestibular neuritis (vestibular neuronitis) is peripheral vertigo without hearing loss; it is secondary to inflammation of the eighth cranial nerve's vestibular segment. The patient has sudden onset of severe, constant vertigo that is exacerbated by head movement and that resolves over days to weeks. The patient may complain of fullness in the ear or tinnitus. The patient may have had an upper respiratory infection in the preceding 2 to 3 weeks. The symptoms may last days.

Common toxins include aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, cytotoxic agents, anticonvulsants, and alcohol. This patient’s medication — lisinopril — is not associated with vertigo.

Ménière disease is characterized by fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, aural fullness, and recurrent severe vertigo with nausea and vomiting that lasts 30 minutes to many hours. Between episodes, the patient’s balance is normal. questions.text: A 42-year-old teacher presents to the ED with continuous vertigo that started 12 hours ago after waking up with nausea. She reports difficulty standing and walking, with a tendency to fall to the left. She denies tinnitus, hearing loss, or focal neurological symptoms. Her vital signs are normal. Examination shows spontaneous horizontal nystagmus with the fast phase beating to the right. The nystagmus is suppressed with visual fixation and remains unidirectional with gaze changes. During head impulse testing, she shows impaired vestibuloocular reflex on the left side with corrective saccades. The test of skew is negative. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical presentation and HINTS findings are consistent with vestibular neuritis. Emergency department management focuses on symptomatic treatment with antiemetics such as ondansetron for nausea and vestibular suppressants such as meclizine for vertigo during the acute phase.

B) INCORRECT:

While corticosteroids may have some benefit for recovery at one month, they are not routinely recommended and are not considered standard emergency department management. The evidence for long-term benefits remains uncertain.

C) INCORRECT:

The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, which manifests with episodic vertigo triggered by position changes. This patient has continuous vertigo that is not position-dependent, which is more consistent with vestibular neuritis.

D) INCORRECT:

The HINTS examination findings are consistent with peripheral vertigo, making central causes unlikely. The abnormal head impulse test, peripheral-type nystagmus, and negative test of skew strongly suggest vestibular neuritis rather than stroke requiring emergency imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Vestibular rehabilitation therapy is important for long-term recovery and should be initiated as soon as possible, but it is not the immediate next step in emergency department management. Acute symptom control is the priority.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of severe, continuous vertigo and nausea. She reports the room feels like it is spinning constantly. The symptoms began abruptly and were preceded by a mild upper respiratory infection last week. She denies any hearing loss, tinnitus, headache, or focal weakness. On examination, she is lying still with her eyes closed. Vital signs are normal. She has horizontal nystagmus that lessens with visual fixation. The head impulse test is positive. Otoscopic and neurologic examinations, including cerebellar testing, are otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a common cause of vertigo, but it manifests as brief, recurrent episodes triggered by specific head movements, such as rolling over in bed or looking up. This patient's vertigo is severe and continuous for 24 hours, which is inconsistent with the episodic nature of BPPV. The head impulse test is also typically normal in BPPV.

B) INCORRECT:

Labyrinthitis can manifest with acute, continuous vertigo following a viral infection. However, labyrinthitis involves inflammation of the whole inner ear. Therefore, it is defined by the presence of both vertigo and new-onset unilateral hearing loss and/or tinnitus, which this patient denies.

C) INCORRECT:

Meniere disease is characterized by a classic triad of episodic vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus. While it causes vertigo, the episodes typically last for minutes to hours, not continuously for a full day. Furthermore, this patient explicitly denies the hallmark auditory symptoms of hearing loss and tinnitus that are present in Meniere disease.

D) CORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis is characterized by the acute onset of severe, continuous vertigo, nausea, and gait instability, often following a viral illness. It is caused by post-viral inflammation of the vestibular nerve (cranial nerve VIII), leading to peripheral vestibular dysfunction. The diagnosis is clinical, supported by key physical examination findings: a positive head impulse test (indicating vestibular hypofunction), horizontal nystagmus that suppresses with visual fixation, and a normal neurologic examination. The crucial differentiating feature is the absence of auditory symptoms (hearing loss or tinnitus), as the inflammation is confined to the vestibular portion of the nerve, sparing the cochlear division. Management is supportive with antiemetics and vestibular suppressants.

E) INCORRECT:

A cerebellar infarction is a critical central cause of vertigo that must be considered. However, several findings are not typical for cerebellar infarction. The positive head impulse test and nystagmus that suppresses with fixation are classic signs of a peripheral, not central, cause. Additionally, this patient's neurologic examination, including specific cerebellar testing, is unremarkable, making a stroke less likely.
questions.hint: The combination of a recent viral illness and the absence of auditory symptoms like hearing loss or tinnitus is key to establishing this patient’s diagnosis.
